definition: A mathematical representation of a set of objects where some pairs of the objects are connected by links.
A fundamental unit in a graph, often represented as a point or node.
A connection between two vertices in a graph, representing a relationship between them.
A graph in which edges have a direction, indicating a one-way relationship between vertices.
A graph in which edges have no direction, representing a two-way relationship between vertices.
A graph in which each edge is assigned a numerical value, called a weight, representing a cost or distance.
A closed path in a graph where the first and last vertices are the same.
A connected acyclic undirected graph, or a connected acyclic directed graph.
A square matrix used to represent a finite graph, where the elements indicate whether pairs of vertices are adjacent or not.
The number of edges incident to a vertex in a graph.
A graph that contains a cycle that includes every edge exactly once.
A subset of vertices in a graph such that every two distinct vertices in the clique are adjacent.
A graph in which there is a path between every pair of vertices.
A vertex whose removal increases the number of connected components in a graph.
An edge whose removal increases the number of connected components in a graph.
An algorithm for finding the shortest paths between nodes in a graph.
An algorithm that finds the shortest paths from a single source vertex to all other vertices in a weighted graph.
An algorithm for finding the shortest paths between all pairs of vertices in a weighted graph.
An algorithm for traversing or searching tree or graph data structures.
An algorithm for traversing or searching tree or graph data structures.
Visiting all the vertices of a graph in a specific order, typically to explore or search the graph.
The smallest number of edges that must be removed to disconnect a graph.
